Tim Conley cites the following: "Philip Howard assembled a list of seven implied meanings for the word "ironically", as it opens a sentence: # By a tragic coincidence # By an exceptional coincidence # By a curious coincidence # By a coincidence of no importance # You and I know, of course, though other less intelligent mortals walk benighted under the midday sun # Oddly enough, or it's a rum thing that # Oh hell! I've run out of words to start a sentence with."Conley, T., ''Joyces Mistakes: Problems of Intention, Irony, and Interpretation'', University of Toronto Press, 2011, p. 81. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cEiRp0yq-noC&pg=PA81&dq=irony+misuse&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uykoUqLRHYSShgez1YDoDg&ved=0CP4BEOgBMCQ#v=onepage&q=irony%20misuse&f=false] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808100009/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cEiRp0yq-noC&pg=PA81&dq=irony+misuse&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uykoUqLRHYSShgez1YDoDg&ved=0CP4BEOgBMCQ |date=2016-08-08 }} ==Punctuation== {{main article|Irony punctuation}} No agreed-upon method for indicating irony in written text exists, though many ideas have been suggested. For instance, an [[Irony punctuation|irony punctuation mark]] was proposed in the 1580s, when Henry Denham introduced a rhetorical question mark or [[percontation point]], which resembles a reversed question mark. This mark was also advocated by the French poet Marcel Bernhardt at the end of the 19th century, to indicate irony or [[sarcasm]]. French writer [[Hervé Bazin]] suggested another ''pointe d'ironie'': the Greek letter ''[[Psi (letter)|psi]]'' {{lang|el|Ψ}} with a dot below it, while [[Tom Driberg]] recommended that ironic statements should be printed in italics that lean the other way from conventional italics.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3fbWAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Houston, K., ''Shady Characters: The Secret Life of Punctuation, Symbols, and Other Typographical Marks'', W. W. Norton & Company, 2013, pp. 211-244.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808104355/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3fbWAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |date=2016-08-08 }} ==See also== *[[Accismus]] *[[Apophasis]] *[[Auto-antonym]] *[[Contradiction]] *[[Double standard]] *[[Hypocrisy]] *[[Ironism]] *[[Irony punctuation]] *[[Meta-communication]] *[[Oxymoron]] *[[Paradox]] *[[Post-irony]] *[[Sarcasm]] *[[Satire]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin|2}} *Bogel, Fredric V. "Irony, Inference, and Critical Understanding." ''Yale Review'', 503–19. *Booth, Wayne C. ''A Rhetoric of Irony''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1975. *Bryant, G. A., & Fox Tree, J. E. (2002). Recognizing verbal irony in spontaneous speech. ''Metaphor and Symbol, 17'', 99–115. *[[Claire Colebrook|Colebrook, Claire]]. ''Irony''. London and New York: Routledge, 2004. *Gibbs, R. W. (2000). Irony in talk among friends. ''Metaphor and Symbol, 15'', 5–27. *Hutcheon, Linda. ''Irony's Edge: The Theory and Politics of Irony''. London: Routledge, 1994. *Kierkegaard, Søren. ''On the Concept of Irony with Continual Reference to Socrates''. 1841; Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1992. *Lavandier, Yves. ''[[Writing Drama]]'', pages 263–315. *Lee, C. J., & Katz, A. N. (1998). The differential role of ridicule in sarcasm and irony. ''Metaphor and Symbol, 13'', 1–15. *Leggitt, J., & Gibbs, R. W. (2000). Emotional reactions to verbal irony. ''Discourse Processes, 29''(1), 1–24. *Muecke, D. C. ''The Compass of Irony''. London: Methuen, 1969. *Star, William T. "Irony and Satire: A Bibliography." Irony and Satire in French Literature. Ed. University of South Carolina Department of Foreign Languages and Literatures. Columbia, SC: University of South Carolina College of Humanities and Social Sciences, 1987. 183–209. {{refend}} ==External links== {{wiktionary|irony}} *"[https://www.theguardian.com/weekend/story/0,,985375,00.html The final irony]"—a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' article about irony, use and misuse of the term *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050308203107/http://sc.tri-bit.com/Irony Article on the etymology of Irony] *[http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=DicHist/uvaGenText/tei/DicHist2.xml;chunk.id=dv2-70 "Irony", by Norman D. Knox], in ''Dictionary of the History of Ideas'' (1973) *"[http://afflatus.ucd.ie/sardonicus/tree.jsp Sardonicus]"—a web-resource that provides access to similes, ironic and otherwise, harvested from the web. *[http://www.clown-enfant.com/leclown/eng/drama/livre.htm#IRO Excerpt on dramatic irony from Yves Lavandier's Writing Drama] ''[[Writing Drama]]'' has a 52-page chapter on dramatic irony (with insights on the three phases (installation-exploitation-resolution), surprise, mystery, suspense, diffuse dramatic irony, etc.) *[http://www.danwallacemusic.com/2010/01/20/american-irony/ "American Irony"] compared with British irony, quoting [[Stephen Fry]] *[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/feb/10/comedy.television American and British irony] compared by [[Simon Pegg]] *[http://www.thespoof.com/news/spoof.cfm?headline=s2i36021 Modern example of ironic writing] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/blackadder/epguide/three_amy.shtml Irony definition by Baldrick (BlackAdder)] {{Narrative modes}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Comedy]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Irony| ]] [[Category:Rhetorical techniques]] [[Category:Fiction]] [[Category:Theme]] [[Category:Tropes by type]]

page.title: List of 20th-century outdoor proponents and outdoor educators

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} Examples of [[misogyny]] exist in many published forms, within multiple cultures and well-observed works.<ref>Hashmi, Taj. [http://www.mukto-mona.com/Articles/taj_hashmi/Popular_Islam_and_Misogyn1.pdf Popular Islam and Misogyny: A Case Study of Bangladesh]. Retrieved October 19, 2011.</ref><ref>Rogers, Katharine M. ''The Troublesome Helpmate: A History of Misogyny in Literature,'' 1966.</ref> Technological advances in the modern era have contributed proficient means to media and marketing to the resultant [[mass media]] in the 21st century. The merging of '''misogyny and mass media''' has made numerous examples where studies have concluded correlations between misogynous messages, both obvious and [[subliminal stimuli|subliminal]]. Corresponding physical appearance of violence and hateful conduct may be seen relative to exposure.<ref name= "Dietz" />
==Music, violence, and aggression==
Messages containing [[misogynous]] views are found commonly in the media.<ref name="Nagayama">Nagayama Hall, Gordon C. "The Influence of Misogynous Rap Music on Sexual Aggression Against Women." Psychology of Women Quarterly. By Christy Barongan. Cambridge UP, 1995. 195–207. Web.</ref><ref name="Wester">{{cite journal | last1 = Wester | first1 = Stephen R. | last2 = Crown | first2 = Cynthia L. | last3 = Quatman | first3 = Gerald L. | last4 = Heesacker | first4 = Martin | year = 1997 | title = The Influence of Sexually Violent Rap Music on Attitudes of Men with Little Prior Exposure | url = | journal = Psychology of Women Quarterly | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 497–508 | doi=10.1111/j.1471-6402.1997.tb00127.x}}</ref> Cooper (1985) found after analyzing [[popular music]] over 30 years, that there was a tendency to describe women in terms of physical attributes or as evil, as possessions of men, or as dependent upon men. Dietz states that the concept of [[masculinity]] has come to be associated with sexual aggression.<ref name="Dietz">{{cite journal | last1 = Dietz | first1 = Tracy L | year = 1998 | title = An Examination of Violence and Gender Role Portrayals in Video Games: Implications for Gender Socialization and Aggressive Behavior | doi = 10.1023/A:1018709905920 | journal = Sex Roles | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 425–41 }}</ref> It is thought that audiences of unpunished violent behavior, compared to audiences of punished violent behavior are more likely to take part in violence.<ref name="Wester" /> Some musical themes and [[lyrics]] can be compared to the negative attitude toward women found within some [[pornographic movies]] and magazines.<ref name="Nagayama" /> This negative attitude and acceptance of [[Violence against women|violence towards women]] shows the possible likelihood of rape or sexual coercion.<ref name=" St.Lawrence">{{cite journal | last1 = St | first1 = | last2 = Lawrence | first2 = Janet S. | last3 = Joyner | first3 = Doris J. | year = 1991 | title = The Effects of Sexually Violent Rock Music on Males' Acceptance of Violence against Women | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-6402.1991.tb00477.x | journal = Psychology of Women Quarterly | volume = 15 | issue = | pages = 49–63 }}</ref> Fischer and Greitemeyer found that men who listened to sexually aggressive music reported that their relationship with women was more troublesome.<ref name="Fischer">{{cite journal | last1 = Fischer | first1 = Peter | last2 = Greitemeyer | first2 = Tobias | year = 2006 | title = Music and Aggression: The Impact of Sexual-Aggressive Song Lyrics on Aggression-Related Thoughts, Emotions and Behavior Toward the Same and the Opposite Sex | url = | journal = Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin | volume = 32 | issue = | pages = 1165–175 | doi=10.1177/0146167206288670}}</ref> Media Violence research has found that aggressive music adds an accessibility of aggressive related attitudes and emotions.<ref name="Fischer" /> Roberta Hamilton in her book ''Does Misogyny Matter?'' (1987) stated,"Misogyny is not a word useful simply for describing particularly nasty bits of behavior, but rather it directs us to a set of relations, attitudes, and behaviors that are embedded within all social relations"(p. 123).<ref>Hamilton, Roberta. Does Misogyny Matter?: Its Reproduction and Its Consequences for Social Progress. Kingston, Ont.: Programme of Studies in National and International Development, Queenś University, 1987</ref><ref name="Adams" /> Violence in the form of linguistics is in fact a form of physical violence.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gorsevski | first1 = Ellen W | year = 1998 | title = The Physical Side of Linguistic Violence | url = | journal = Peace Review | volume = 10 | issue = 4| page = 513 }}</ref><ref name="Armstrong"/>
Rubin, West and Mitchell (2001) found that many studies have seen consumers of [[rap]] and [[heavy metal music]] as having more hostile attitudes, higher sexual activity and more drug use than consumers of other music.<ref name= "Fischer" />
=== Gangsta rap === [[File:Eminem performing live at dj hero party.jpg|thumb|upright|Eminem performing live at the ''[[DJ Hero]]'' Party in Los Angeles]] Themes of misogyny can be seen in much [[gangsta rap]] (GR) music. This music elevates degradations of women such as rape, torment, and violence. In a study conducted by Armstrong in 2001, he found after examining 490 GR songs, that 22 percent contained violent and misogynist lyrics.<ref name="Armstrong">{{cite journal | last1 = Armstrong | first1 = Edward G | year = 2001 | title = Gangsta Misogyny: A Content Analysis of the Portrayals of Violence Against Women in Rap Music, 1987–1993 | url = | journal = Journal of Criminal Justice and Popular Culture | volume = 8 | issue = 2| pages = 96–126 }}</ref> Wester, Crown, Quatman, and Heesacker state that, "The increasing popularity of GR, coupled with documentation of society's increased [[sexism]],<ref>Faludi, 1991; Zillmann &Bryant, 1982, 1984</ref> domestic violence,<ref>Koss et al. 1994; [[Catharine MacKinnon]] 1993</ref> sexual assault<ref>MacKinnon, 1993; Malamuth, 1981</ref> and other forms of degradation of women<ref>[[Andrea Dworkin]], 1979, 1988; MacKinnon, 1985, 1989, 1993</ref> suggest that perhaps GR is partly to blame for an increase in anti-female attitudes and behaviors. It is difficult to tell whether GR directly causes misogynous attitudes or if it serves to increase preexisting anti-female cultural values.<ref name="Wester" /><ref>Bryant, Jennings, and Dolf Zillmann. Media Effects: Advances in Theory and Research. Mahwah, NJ: L. Elbaum Associates, 2002. web.</ref><ref>Faludi, Susan. Backlash: the Undeclared War against American Women. New York: Anchor, 1992. Web.</ref><ref>MacKinnon, Catharine A. Women's Lives, Men's Laws. Cambridge, MA: Belknap of Harvard UP.2005. Web.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Malamuth | first1 = Neil M | year = 1981 | title = Rape Proclivity Among Males | url = | journal = Journal of Social Issues | volume = 37 | issue = 4| pages = 138–54 | doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1981.tb01075.x}}</ref><ref>Dworkin, Andrea. "Against the Male Flood: Censorship, Pornography and Equality." Harvard Women's Law Journal (1985).</ref> The difference between rap music and other types of music is that the [[lyrics]] are generally the main focus of attention.<ref name="Nagayama" /> Rappers seem to commit themselves to worst impulses by telling their stories in the first-person.<ref name="Armstrong" />
In a study conducted by Barongan and Hall (1995), they had male college students listen to rap music with misogynous or neutral song lyrics. After listening to the different music, they viewed three different vignettes. These vignettes were either sexual-violent, neutral, or assaultive. Then the students were asked to choose one of the three vignettes to show a female. Those who had listened to the misogynous music were significantly more likely to show the female the assaultive vignette.<ref name="Fischer" />
Regarding gangsta rap [[Yo-Yo (rapper)|Yo-Yo]] states that, "The harder that you are, sad to say, the more you sell".<ref name="Armstrong" /><ref>Jones, James T. IV. 1993. "Female Rappers Go With the Gangsta Flow." USA Today (October 5): 6D.</ref>
=== Hip-hop === Misogyny was not found in [[rap music]] until the 1980s even though it had been in the commercial market for 10 years. Some artists such as [[2 Live Crew]], [[Ice-T]], and [[N.W.A.]] integrated misogynous lyrics into their rap songs. Women are reduced to objects – specifically objects that are only good for abuse, sex and for the most part are just trouble for men within misogynous rap. Using such misogynistic lyrics allows degradation of their female counterparts while boosting themselves up.<ref name="Adams">{{cite journal | last1 = Adams | first1 = Terri M. | last2 = Fuller | first2 = Douglas B. | year = 2006 | title = The Words Have Changed but the Ideology Remains the Same Misogynistic Lyrics in Rap Music | url = | journal = Journal of Black Studies | volume = 36 | issue = 6| pages = 938–57 | doi=10.1177/0021934704274072}}</ref>
This acceptance of misogyny can be seen in many rap lyrics. For example, in N.W.A's "She Swallowed It" (1991) gives a clear description;<ref name="Armstrong" /><ref>"One Less Bitch." Efil4zaggin. Ruthless/Priority. CDL 57126.</ref>
{{Quote box |quote = Punch the bitch in the eye/ then the ho will fall to the ground/ Then you open up her mouth/ put your dick, move the shit around. |source = — [[N.W.A]], "She Swallowed It" |width = 50% |align = center}}
Scenes of physical harm can be seen in Too $hort "All My Bitches Are Gone"(1993);<ref name="Armstrong" /><ref>1993a. "All My Bitches Are Gone." Get In Where You Fit In. Jive/Zomba. 01241-41526-2.</ref>
{{Quote box |quote = You fuck with us, bitch, something gettin' broken/ Your leg, arm, jaw, nose, pick a part. |source = — [[Too $hort]], "All My Bitches Are Gone" |width = 50% |align = center}}
The artist [[Eminem]] is well known for his rap music containing extremely misogynous lyrics. In 2002 his Album ''The Eminem Show'' sold 7.4 million copies.<ref name="Fischer" />
=== Heavy metal === In a study conducted by Lawrence and Joyner, it was found that people exposed to sexually violent or [[heavy metal music]] were found to have a higher tendency on sex-role stereotyping in comparison to those who listened to classical music.<ref name="St.Lawrence" /> Researchers suggest that; distrust, assault, and negative regard for women are common attitudes experienced by fans of different types of rock music.<ref name="St.Lawrence" /><ref name ="Arnett">{{cite journal | last1 = Arnett | first1 = Jeffery | year = 1991 | title = Heavy Metal Music and Reckless Behavior Among Adolescents | url = | journal = Journal of Youth and Adolescence | volume = 20 | issue = 6| pages = 573–92 | doi=10.1007/bf01537363}}</ref>
=== Inconclusive link === Most violent lyrics are not heard due to the fact a large number of listeners are not actually listening to the lyrics. This is very different from video-based media, in which the audience can see the violent message very clearly. It has also been found that some rock lyrics are so distorted that people just assume what they are actually saying. A majority of people often listen to just the music and not the lyrics while some listen to it while focusing on other tasks.<ref>Anderson, Craig A., Nicholas L. Carnagey, and Janie Eubanks. "Exposure to Violent Media: The Effects of Songs With Violent Lyrics on Aggressive Thoughts and Feelings." Journal of Personality and Social Psychology 5th ser. 84 (2003): 960–71. Web.</ref>
Research of rap music also suggests that it may contain positive images. Zillman et al. proposed that rap music is used as a way to fight oppression from the dominant culture.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Zillmann | first1 = D. | last2 = Aust | first2 = C. | last3 = Hoffman | first3 = K. | last4 = Love | first4 = C. | last5 = Ordman | first5 = V.Pope | year = 1995 | title = Radical rap: Does it further ethnic division? | url = | journal = Basic and Applied Social Psychology | volume = 16 | issue = 1–2| pages = 1–25 | doi=10.1080/01973533.1995.9646098}}</ref> It was also found by Kubrin that 68 percent of all gangsta rap's focal point is about respect.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kubrin | first1 = C | year = 2005 | title = Gangstas, thugs, and hustlas: Identity and the code of the street in rap music | url = | journal = Social Problems | volume = 52 | issue = 3| pages = 360–378 | doi=10.1525/sp.2005.52.3.360}}</ref><ref name="Conrad">{{cite journal | last1 = Conrad | first1 = Kate | last2 = Dixon | first2 = Travis L. | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Yuanyuan | year = 2009 | title = Controversial Rap Themes, Gender Portrayals and Skin Tone Distortion: A Content Analysis of Rap Music Videos | url = | journal = Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media | volume = 53 | issue = 1| pages = 134–56 | doi=10.1080/08838150802643795}}</ref> It is a "cultural response to historic oppression and racism, [and] a system for communication among black communities throughout the United States." With both gleeful and aggressive views on the situation of black Americans, Hip Hop artists were spread reality and lessons learned in a way that is understandable by a younger generation.<ref name="America: History & Life, EBSCOhost">{{cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=Layli|last2=Reddick-Morgan|first2=Kerri|last3=Patricia Stephens|first3=Dionne|title=Oppositional Consciousness within an Oppositional Realm: The Case of Feminism and Womanism in Rap and Hip Hop, 1976-2004|journal=Journal of African American History|date=2005|volume=3|issue=90|pages=253–77|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=43da7d3b-53a1-4d49-b50e-fab440498f53%40sessionmgr115&vid=14&hid=125|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref> Some call it a "street-leveling language".<ref name="America: History & Life, EBSCOhost">{{cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=Layli|last2=Reddick-Morgan|first2=Kerri|last3=Patricia Stephens|first3=Dionne|title=Oppositional Consciousness within an Oppositional Realm: The Case of Feminism and Womanism in Rap and Hip Hop, 1976-2004|journal=Journal of African American History|date=2005|volume=3|issue=90|pages=253–77|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=43da7d3b-53a1-4d49-b50e-fab440498f53%40sessionmgr115&vid=14&hid=125|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
==Violent and aggressive videos==
===In music=== [[Image:AMTV.png|thumb|''[[AMTV]]'', the name of MTV's music programming since 2009]] Felson, professor of crime, law, and justice and sociology at Penn State, states that a crowd of onlookers enjoys a street fight just as the Romans enjoyed the [[gladiators]].<ref name="Felson">{{cite journal | last1 = Felson | first1 = Richard B | year = 1996 | title = Mass Media Effects on Violent Behavior | url = | journal = Annual Review of Sociology | volume = 22 | issue = | pages = 103–28 | doi=10.1146/annurev.soc.22.1.103}}</ref> Found frequently in ''MTV'' music videos are images of crime, sex, dance, visual abstraction and violence. Audiences of ''MTV'' tend to be between the ages of fourteen and thirty-four, therefore has potential of contributing to cultural norms.<ref name="Baxter">{{cite journal | last1 = Baxter | first1 = Richard L. | last2 = De Riemer | first2 = Cynthia | last3 = Landini | first3 = Ann | last4 = Leslie | first4 = Larry | last5 = Singletary | first5 = Michael W. | year = 1985 | title = A Content Analysis of Music Videos | url = | journal = Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media | volume = 29 | issue = 3| pages = 333–340 | doi=10.1080/08838158509386589}}</ref> Smith and Boyson found that fifteen percent of music videos contain violence.<ref name="Smith">Smith, Stacy L., and Aaron R. Boyson. Violence in Music Videos: Examining the Prevalence and Context of Physical Aggression. Michigan State University, Department of Communication. International Communication Association, 2002.</ref> Before the introduction of music videos, research found that both music and television retained adolescents' attention, but music effectively connected with their emotions.<ref name="Rich">{{cite journal | last1 = Rich | first1 = Michael | last2 = Woods | first2 = Elizabeth R. | last3 = Goodman | first3 = Elizabeth | last4 = Emans | first4 = S. Jean | last5 = DuRant | first5 = Robert H. | year = 1998 | title = Aggressors or Victims: Gender and Race in Music Video Violence | url = | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 101 | issue = 4| pages = 669–73 | doi=10.1542/peds.101.4.669}}</ref> It is far more common to see a man being dominant over a woman, rather than a woman being dominant over a man in music videos.<ref name="Andsager">Andsager, Julie, and Kimberly Roe. "What's Your Definition of Dirty, Baby?" Sexuality and Culture. School of Journalism and Mass Communication, University of Iowa, 2003.</ref><ref name="Sommers">{{cite journal | last1 = Sommers-Flanagan | first1 = Rita | last2 = Sommers-Flanagan | first2 = John | last3 = Davis | first3 = Britta | year = 1993 | title = What's Happening on Music Television | url = | journal = Sex Roles | volume = 28 | issue = | pages = 745–53 | doi=10.1007/bf00289991}}</ref> A study conducted by Rich, Woods, Goodman, Emans, and DuRant found that out of 518 music videos and among the 391 acts of violence the aggressors were 78 percent male and the victims were 46 percent female.<ref name="Rich" /> The need for artists to fill hours of airtime on television make certain that artists and their videos increasingly become more shocking, as to be noticed. Violence and sex or the combination of the two, are most often used for a [[Shock value|shocking effect]] on viewers.<ref name="Andsager" />
==== Rock ==== In a content analysis of rock music videos, Vincent, Davis and Boruszkowski found that 57 percent showed women in a "patronizing" way (such as; victims, sex objects, and stupid) and 20 percent of them were found placed in traditional sex roles (domestic, motherly, and submissive), another eight percent demonstrated women receiving violence from a male. The amount where women were shown as equal to men was only fourteen percent.<ref name= "Vincent">{{cite journal | last1 = Vincent | first1 = R. C. | last2 = Davis | first2 = D. K. | last3 = Boruszkowski | first3 = L. A. | year = 1987 | title = Sexism on MTV: The portrayal of women in rock videos | url = | journal = Journalism Quarterly | volume = 64 | issue = 750–755| page = 941 }}</ref><ref name="Weitzer">Weitzer, Ronald, and Charis E. Kubrin. "Misogyny in Rap Music: A Content Analysis of Prevalence and Meanings." Men and Masculinities 12.1 (2009): 3–29.</ref> Lawrence and Joyner found in their research of rock music videos that even after a brief exposure of seventeen minutes there was appearance of negative effects on men's attitudes toward women.<ref name=" St.Lawrence" />
==== Rap ==== Johnson et al. found that women portrayed in sexually inferior roles in rap music videos have increased girls’ acceptance of teen dating violence. They also found that these videos did not increase boy's acceptance of teen violence.<ref name="Kalof">{{cite journal | last1 = Kalof | first1 = Linda | year = 1999 | title = The Effects of Gender and Music Video Imagery on Sexual Attitudes | url = | journal = The Journal of Social Psychology | volume = 139 | issue = 3| pages = 378–385 | doi=10.1080/00224549909598393 | pmid=10410622}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = J.D. | last2 = Adams | first2 = M.S. | last3 = Ashburn | first3 = L. | last4 = Reed | first4 = W. | year = 1995 | title = Differential gender effects of exposure to rap music on African American adolescents' acceptance of teen dating violence | url = | journal = Sex Roles | volume = 33 | issue = | pages = 597–605 | doi=10.1007/bf01544683}}</ref> Sommers-Flanagan found that not only are women shown in a position of submission to men, they are also shown in a more negative light than men in rap music videos.<ref name="Conrad">{{cite journal | last1 = Conrad | first1 = Kate | last2 = Dixon | first2 = Travis L. | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Yuanyuan | year = 2009 | title = Controversial Rap Themes, Gender Portrayals and Skin Tone Distortion: A Content Analysis of Rap Music Videos | url = | journal = Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media | volume = 53 | issue = 1| pages = 134–56 | doi=10.1080/08838150802643795}}</ref><ref name="Sommers" /> Conrad et al. found that recent (2009) rap music videos emphasize themes of misogyny, materialism and women tend to be placed in a position of objectification.<ref name="Conrad" />
In addition to women being placed in objectified positions, they are "criticized and loved at the same time for being covered up versus being scantily dressed."<ref name="America: History & Life, EBSCOhost2">{{cite journal|last1=Rebollo-Gil|first1=Guillermo|last2=Moras|first2=Amanda|title=Black Women and Black Men in Hip Hop Music: Misogyny, Violence and the Negotiation of (White-Owned) Space|journal=Journal of Popular Culture|date=2012|volume=1|issue=45|pages=118–32|doi=10.1111/j.1540-5931.2011.00898.x}}</ref> Women in the rap industry are most commonly only mentioned by the media when it is to further stigmatize men, or to promote the stereotype that all black women are on welfare or are gold-diggers.<ref name="America: History & Life, EBSCOhost2">{{cite journal|last1=Rebollo-Gil|first1=Guillermo|last2=Moras|first2=Amanda|title=Black Women and Black Men in Hip Hop Music: Misogyny, Violence and the Negotiation of (White-Owned) Space|journal=Journal of Popular Culture|date=2012|volume=1|issue=45|pages=118–32|doi=10.1111/j.1540-5931.2011.00898.x}}</ref>
===Video games=== In a 1998 study conducted by Tracy L. Dietz, professor of [[Sociology]] & [[Anthropology]] at the [[University of Central Florida]], sampled 33 prominent Nintendo and Sega games and found that nearly 80 percent of the video games had some violence and aggression as part of the main strategy or object. Dietz claimed that violence was directed specifically towards women in 21% of the games sampled. Also in 28 percent of the games women were, according to Dietz, seen as sex objects and in 41 percent of the games there were no female characters. Overall Dietz asserted that most video games minimize the role of females or leave females out of the game all together, and that when females were shown they were usually depicted in a supporting role to men or dependent upon the male. Women were also seen as contributing less than males and were their sex objects. Dietz stated that these depictions of women may allow boys and girls to internalize and accept the thought that women are victims, weak, and sex objects.<ref name= "Dietz" />
==Violent pornography== By making misogyny sexual, pornography teaches misogyny to its viewers.<ref>Witt, Charlotte. "Pornography." The Johns Hopkins University Press 9.2 (1997): 165–74.</ref> Negative effects from pornography have been thought to occur due to a violence component, and not to a sexual component. Males who have been previously enraged by a female are more likely to produce aggression against a female after being shown pornography depicting violence.<ref name="Padgett">{{cite journal | last1 = Padgett | first1 = Vernon R. | last2 = Jo Ann | first2 = Brislin-Slütz | last3 = Neal | first3 = James A. | year = 1989 | title = Pornography, Erotica and Attitudes toward Women: The Effects of Repeated Exposure | url = | journal = The Journal of Sex Research | volume = 26 | issue = 4| pages = 479–91 | doi=10.1080/00224498909551529}}</ref> The combination of sex and aggression is increasingly being shown within pornographic material, therefore could be a possible trigger for aggressively willing men to physical assault accessible women.<ref name= "Donnerstein">{{cite journal | last1 = Donnerstein | first1 = Edward | last2 = Berkowitz | first2 = Leonard | year = 1981 | title = Victim Reactions in Aggressive Erotic Films as a Factor in Violence against Women | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 41 | issue = 4| pages = 710–24 | doi=10.1037/0022-3514.41.4.710}}</ref> The attorney general's commission found that viewing of sexually aggressive pornography is causally connected to sexual violent behavior.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.porn-report.com/521-sexually-violent-material.htm | title=''Attorney General's Commission on Pornography'' | publisher=United States Attorney General | date=July 1986 | accessdate=9 April 2015 | at=sec 5.2.1}}</ref> Sexual violence portrayed in pornography as pleasurable to the victim may increase approval of sexual coercion, there by relating to sexual violence.<ref name="St.Lawrence" /><ref name="Koop">{{cite journal | last1 = Koop | first1 = Everett C | year = 1987 | title = Report of the Surgeon General's Workshop on Pornography and Public Health | url = | journal = American Psychologist | volume = 42 | issue = 10| pages = 944–45 | doi=10.1037/0003-066x.42.10.944}}</ref><ref>Mulvey, E. P., & Haugaard, J. L. (1986, August). Report of the Surgeon General's Workshop on Pornography and Public Health. Washington, DC: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Office of the Surgeon General.</ref> A common theme found within pornography is women enjoying victimization. This theme can be seen to give reason for violence and decrease general inhibitions against aggression.<ref name="Donnerstein" /><ref>Barry, K ''Female sexual slavery''. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.:Prentice-Hall, 1979.</ref><ref>Gager, N., & Schurr, C. ''Sexual assault: Confronting rape in America''. New York:Grosset & Dunlap, 1976.</ref>
=== Usenet === Barron and Kimmel found that [[Usenet]] contains less consensual sex and more coercive sex in the scenes depicted. Within Usenet it was found that 62.7 percent of the scenes had a male perpetrators and only 42.4 percent of the scenes contained female perpetrators. Victims within Usenet was found to be females 84.7 percent of the time. At nearly no expense Usenet offers the greatest access to the largest number of viewers.<ref name=Barron>{{cite journal | last1 = Barron | first1 = Martin | last2 = Kimmel | first2 = Michael | year = 2000 | title = Sexual Violence in Three Pornographic Media: Toward a Sociological Explanation | url = | journal = The Journal of Sex Research | volume = 37 | issue = 2| pages = 161–68 | doi=10.1080/00224490009552033}}</ref>
=== Influencing misogyny ===
A summary of the effects of pornography research by Linz and Donnerstein (1989) concluded that depictions of sexual violence in the media, under some conditions, promote antisocial attitudes and behavior. Linz and Donnerstein focused on the detrimental effects of exposure to violent images in pornography portraying the myth that women enjoy or in some way benefit from rape, torture, or other forms of sexual violence. Other research has found similar outcomes (e.g., Allen et al., 1995). The viewing of coercive pornography relates to the strongest acceptance of [[rape myths]], i.e. women want to be raped, women "ask for it", women want to be forced. Considering the commodification and objectification argument, concern exists that repeated exposure to coercive pornographic stimuli relates to increasingly negative attitudes toward women. More frequent use increased the dehumanizing effect of Internet pornography and led to more acceptance of violence toward women.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Effects of long-term exposure to violent and sexually degrading depictions of women|pmid=3210143|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.55.5.758|journal=J Pers Soc Psychol|year=1988|volume=55|issue=5|pages=758–68|vauthors=Linz DG, Donnerstein E, Penrod S}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
Pornography has been found to desensitize societies to violence against women, inspiring rapes and contributing to the sexual subordination of women to men (2009). Making their materials, pornographers exploit existing inequality between the sexes to coerce women and children to perform unwanted or dangerous sexual acts as a form of prostitution. Existing legal regulations in democratic societies have not approached pornography with these realities in mind, but usually rather as a right protected by freedom of expression, or as an "obscene" expression offending the public rather than harming any particular group. In rare but important instances, pornography has legally been seen as a harmful practice violating women's human or democratic rights to equality.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE CIVIL RIGHTS AND EQUALITY DEFICIT: Legal Challenges to Pornography and Sex Inequality in Canada, Sweden, and the U.S.|url=http://www.cpsa-acsp.ca/papers-2009/Waltman.pdf}}</ref>
Most studies consistently show that after exposure to pornography and other forms of misogynistic media depicting degradation of women and rape, including hip hop and rap, viewers show attitudes that are less sympathetic to rape victims and more tolerant and accepting of violence toward women – in effect, such behavior becomes more "normalized" and "mainstreamed. It's desensitizing and addictive potentials are well-documented in its users."<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.lionlamb.org/mediaviolencefactsheet.pdf|title=The Influence of Media Violence on Youth|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050206052957/http://lionlamb.org/mediaviolencefactsheet.pdf|archivedate=February 6, 2005|journal=Psychological Science in the Public Interest|year=2003|volume=4|number=3|authors=Craig A. Anderson, Leonard Berkowitz, Edward Donnerstein, L. Rowell Huesmann, James D. Johnson, Daniel Linz, Neil M. Malamuth, and Ellen Wartella|doi=10.1111/j.1529-1006.2003.pspi_1433.x|pages=81–110}}</ref>
== Internet misogyny == Internet misogyny is enacted in different forms and on different platforms. When one objectifies or harasses online, they are likely doing so anonymously and using shaming tactics to stigmatize the victim's identity or body. In this anonymity, the objectifier averts all real-life responsibility while nonetheless enforcing real-life consequences for the woman.<ref name=":0">Levmore, Saul X., and Martha Craven Nussbaum. ''The Offensive Internet: Speech, Privacy, and Reputation''. Harvard University Press, 2012.</ref> This tactic of anonymity fosters Internet objectification because it allows the objectifier to create a desired situation where the woman deals with the responsibilities instead of the objectifier.<ref name=":0" />
== See also == * [[Exploitation of women in mass media]] * [[Gender studies]] * [[Misandry]] * [[Misanthropy]] * [[Misogyny in hip hop culture]] * [[Misogyny in horror films]] * [[Misogyny in sports]] * [[Sexism]] * [[Sexuality in music videos]] * ''[[The Bro Code: How Contemporary Culture Creates Sexist Men]]''
==References== {{reflist|3}}
[[Category:Gender]] [[Category:Misogyny|Mass media and misogyny]] [[Category:Sexuality and gender-related prejudices]] [[Category:Mass media]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Monsters vs. Aliens'' (franchise)}} {{Infobox media franchise |title = Monsters vs. Aliens |image = Monsters vs. Aliens logo.png |creator = [[DreamWorks Animation]] |films = * {{nowrap|''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' (2009)}} |shorts = * ''[[B.O.B.'s Big Break]]'' (2009) * ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space]]'' (2009) * ''[[#Monsters vs. Aliens: Night of the Living Carrots|Night of the Living Carrots]]'' (2011) |atv = * {{nowrap|''[[Monsters vs. Aliens (TV series)|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' (2013-2014)}} |vgs = * ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens (video game)|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' * ''[[Super Star Kartz]]'' |soundtracks = * ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens#Soundtrack|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' }} '''''Monsters vs. Aliens''''' is a [[media franchise]] created by [[DreamWorks Animation]]. The franchise began with the 2009 film ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' and has since grown to include a short film, two television specials, a television series, and a video game. The franchise involves a group of monsters who are assigned by the [[US Government]] to defend [[Earth]] from various [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] and [[supernatural]] threats. ==Feature film== {{main|Monsters vs. Aliens}} ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' is a 2009 American [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] 3-D [[science fiction]] [[action comedy]] [[film]]. It was DreamWorks Animation's first feature film to be directly produced in a [[stereoscopy|stereoscopic]] 3-D format instead of being converted into 3-D after completion, which added $15 million to the film's budget.{{cite news |first= Susan |last= Wloszczyna |title=First look: ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' is the ultimate; a 3-D 'first' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2008-03-10-monsters-aliens_N.htm |work=USA Today|date= March 11, 2008|accessdate=May 16, 2008 }} The film was scheduled for a May 2009 release, but the release date was moved to March 27, 2009. It was released on DVD and Blu-ray September 29, 2009, in North America and included the easter egg to the upcoming movies and previews. The film features the voices of [[Reese Witherspoon]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Hugh Laurie]], [[Will Arnett]], [[Conrad Vernon]], [[Rainn Wilson]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], [[Stephen Colbert]], and [[Paul Rudd]]. ===Possible sequel=== In April 2011, [[Jeffrey Katzenberg]] commented that the studio did not have plans to produce future movie genre parodies, like ''[[Shark Tale]]'', ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', and ''[[Megamind]]'', saying that these films "all shared an approach and tone and idea of parody, and did not travel well internationally. We don't have anything like that coming on our schedule now."{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2011/04/dreamworks-pins-hopes-on-kung-fu-panda-2-after-first-quarter-earnings-fall-short-125845/|title=DreamWorks Animation Pins Hopes On 'Kung Fu Panda 2' After 1Q Earnings Fall Short|last=Lieberman|first=David|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=April 26, 2011|accessdate=August 22, 2015}} ==Short films== ===''B.O.B.'s Big Break''=== ''B.O.B.'s Big Break'' is a 3D animated short film. The short premiered on [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] in 2D on September 26, 2009, and was released 3 days later in 2D and 3D on the ''Monsters vs Aliens'' [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] and the double DVD pack.{{cite news|title=The Smash Hit Comedy, MONSTERS VS. ALIENS, Gets Even Bigger September 29, 2009 on DVD and Blu-ray With the World Premiere of B.O.B.'S BIG BREAK the All New Adventure in Monster 3D|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-smash-hit-comedy-monsters-vs-aliens-gets-even-bigger-september-29-2009-on-dvd-and-blu-ray-with-the-world-premiere-of-bobs-big-break-the-all-new-adventure-in-monster-3d-62145287.html|accessdate=September 9, 2011|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation ''via'' PR Newswire|date=July 8, 2009}} B.O.B., Dr. Cockroach, PhD, and The Missing Link are trying to outwit Captain W.R. Monger to escape from Area 52, the government's top-secret holding cell. Cockroach's escape attempt by feeding B.O.B. a chemical mixture to turn him into a bomb instead results in B.O.B. temporarily acquiring the ability to read minds, and allowing them to find out about a secret exit from Area 52. Unfortunately, the plan fails when B.O.B. smashes the jet they were using to escape believing it to be a [[piñata]], with the resulting explosion erasing B.O.B.'s new power. ===''Night of the Living Carrots''=== {{main|Night of the Living Carrots}} ''Night of the Living Carrots'' is a 2011 13-minute{{cite news|last=Gaudiosi|first=John|title=Nintendo Partners with DreamWorks Animation for Exclusive 3DS Video Content|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/nintendo-3ds-dreamworks-animation-shrek-243627|accessdate=October 4, 2011|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 5, 2011}} 3D Halloween short film based on ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', and a sequel to [[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space|''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'']]. It was directed by Robert Porter. First part of the short premiered on October 13, 2011,{{cite news|title=NINTENDO DOWNLOAD HIGHLIGHTS NEW DIGITAL CONTENT FOR NINTENDO SYSTEMS – OCTOBER 13, 2011|url=http://press.nintendo.com/articles.jsp?id=31189|accessdate=October 13, 2011|newspaper=Nintendo|date=October 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015180844/http://press.nintendo.com/articles.jsp?id=31189|archivedate=October 15, 2011|df=mdy-all}} and the second part five days later,{{cite web|title=Night of the Living Carrots Part 1|url=https://www.nintendo.com/3ds/nintendo-video/detail/lPUX7AWBxl45Xwa_lNh55DBxpYS_KFaA|work=Nintendo|accessdate=October 14, 2011}} for a limited time, exclusively on the [[Nintendo 3DS]] video service.{{cite news|title=ADDING MULTIMEDIA DreamWorks Animation, 3net, Blue Man Group Provide 3D Videos for Nintendo 3DS|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111004005743/en/ADDING-MULTIMEDIA-DreamWorks-Animation-3net-Blue-Man|accessdate=October 4, 2011|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation ''via'' Business Wire|date=October 4, 2011}} It was released on August 28, 2012, on DVD and Blu-ray as a part of ''Shrek's Thrilling Tales'' (''DreamWorks Spooky Stories''). Following the cliff hanger at the end of ''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'', the mutated carrot has spawned hundreds of zombie carrots which once they bite a victim they take control of the subject's mind. Dr. Cockroach determines that the only way to defeat the carrots and free their victims is for B.O.B. to eat all of the carrots (specifically because B.O.B. has no brain and thus is immune to the carrots' mind control powers), which B.O.B eventually, albeit reluctantly, does. At the end of the short, B.O.B. is turned into a giant zombie carrot. ==Television special== ===''Monsters vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space''=== {{main|Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space}} ''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'' is a 2009 Halloween special, directed by [[Peter Ramsey]]. It premiered in Ireland on [[RTÉ One]] on October 26, 2009, and aired in USA on the [[NBC]] channel on October 28, 2009.{{cite news|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins From Outer Space|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117941440?refCatId=32|accessdate=August 27, 2011|newspaper=Variety|date=October 23, 2009}} The special was first released on DVD in the UK on September 27, 2010, exclusive to Tesco stores, and in US it was released on September 13, 2011,{{cite web|title=Monsters Vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins Outer Space (2009)|url=https://www.amazon.com/Monsters-Vs-Aliens-Mutant-Pumpkins/dp/B0056YMDVE|work=Amazon|accessdate=August 27, 2011}} and on September 27, 2011,{{cite web|title=Scared Shrekless & Monsters Vs Pumpkins Halloween|url=https://www.amazon.com/Scared-Shrekless-Monsters-Pumpkins-Halloween/dp/B0056YMDSC|work=Amazon|accessdate=August 27, 2011}} along with ''[[Scared Shrekless]]''.{{cite news|title=Scared Shrekless and Monsters vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space Halloween Party Double Pack|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Paramount/2011/08/22/scared_shrekless_and_monsters_vs_alien|accessdate=August 27, 2011|newspaper=Starpulse.com|date=August 22, 2011}} It was released on DVD{{cite web|title=Shrek's Thrilling Tales (Widescreen)|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/21014123|publisher=[[Walmart]]|accessdate=July 20, 2012}} and Blu-ray{{cite web|title=Dreamwork's Spooky Stories: Shreks Thrilling Tales / Scared Shrekless / Mutant Pumpkins From Outer Space (Blu-ray) (Widescreen)|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/21014103|publisher=[[Walmart]]|accessdate=July 20, 2012}} on August 28, 2012, as a part of ''Shrek's Thrilling Tales'' (''DreamWorks Spooky Stories''). Susan and the fellow monsters go back to Susan's home in Modesto, California; just in time for Halloween celebrations. Susan spends time with her parents, while the other monsters join in trick-or-treating and collect a large amount of candy. Later, it is revealed that the monsters came to destroy mutant pumpkins disguised as Jack-o-lanterns. When the pumpkins begin to eat children's candies to grow larger, the monsters and children defeat them by throwing excessive candy to bloat them up and explode them. But, in a [[twist ending]], some of the pumpkin "blood" (a green goo that mutated the ordinary pumpkins) falls into a planting of carrots, causing a mutant carrot to be formed. ==Television series== ===''Monsters vs. Aliens''=== {{Main|Monsters vs. Aliens (TV series)}} A computer-animated television series based on the film, titled ''Monsters vs. Aliens'', aired on [[Nickelodeon]] between March 23, 2013 and February 8, 2014. A total of 26{{cite press release|title=Nickelodeon Unveils Plans at Annual Upfront for More than 650 New Episodes Across Every Genre|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nickelodeon-unveils-plans-at-annual-upfront-for-more-than-650-new-episodes-across-every-genre-142666635.html|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=February 20, 2014|author=Nickelodeon|date=March 12, 2012}} episodes consisting of 2 11-minute segments were released. The cast featured new voice actors for the characters of Dr. Cockroach ([[Chris O'Dowd]]), Susan ([[Riki Lindhome]]), Link ([[Diedrich Bader]]), and B.O.B. ([[Eric Edelstein]]).{{cite web|last=Zahed|first=Ramin|title=‘Monsters vs. Aliens’ Series Debuts on Nick This Sat.|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/monsters-vs-aliens-series-debuts-on-nick-this-sat/|publisher=Animation Magazine|accessdate=February 20, 2014|date=March 18, 2013}} This series was partly produced by New Zealand CG animation studio Oktobor Animation.{{cite web|last=Armstrong|first=Josh|title=Monsters vs. Aliens TV series trailer premieres|url=http://animatedviews.com/2013/monsters-vs-aliens-tv-series-trailer-premieres/|publisher=Animated Views|accessdate=February 20, 2014|date=March 15, 2013}} The series was cancelled after one season due to low ratings and plans to refocus on more "Nickish" shows.{{cite tweet |user=bob_schooley |number=435230104319295490 |author=Schooley, Bob |author-link=Bob Schooley |date=February 16, 2014 |access-date=February 20, 2014 |title=@tlrledbetter Ratings, desire of Nick to get back to the more “Nickish” shows.}} ==Cast and characters== {{main|List of Monsters vs. Aliens characters}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="3" style="width:15%;" | Characters ! Feature film ! colspan="2" | Short films ! Television special ! Television series |- ! style="width:15%;" | ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' ! style="width:15%;" | ''[[B.O.B.'s Big Break]]'' ! style="width:15%;" | ''[[Night of the Living Carrots]]'' ! style="width:15%;" | ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space|{{small|Monsters vs. Aliens:}}
Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space]]'' ! style="width:15%;" | ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens (TV series)|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' |- ! colspan="2" | 2009 ! 2011 ! 2009 ! 2013-2014 |- ! Susan Murphy / Ginormica | [[Reese Witherspoon]] | style="background:lightgrey;" |   | {{N/A|''Archive footage''}} | Reese Witherspoon | [[Riki Lindhome]] |- ! B.O.B. | colspan="4" | [[Seth Rogen]] | [[Eric Edelstein]] |- ! Dr. Cockroach Ph.D. | colspan="2" | [[Hugh Laurie]] | [[James Horan (actor)|James Horan]] | Hugh Laurie | [[Chris O'Dowd]] |- ! rowspan="2" | The Missing Link | rowspan="2" colspan="2" | [[Will Arnett]] | [[David Kaye (voice actor)|David Kaye]] | rowspan="2" | Will Arnett | rowspan="2" | [[Diedrich Bader]] |- | {{N/A|Will Arnett}}
{{small|(''archive recording'')}} |- ! Insectosaurus / Butterflyosaurus | [[Conrad Vernon]] | colspan="2" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | Conrad Vernon | style="background:lightgrey;" |   |- ! General Warren R. Monger | colspan="4" | [[Kiefer Sutherland]] | [[Kevin Michael Richardson]] |- ! Gallaxhar | [[Rainn Wilson]] | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;"|   |- ! rowspan="2" | President Hathaway | rowspan="2" | [[Stephen Colbert]] | rowspan="2" colspan="2" style="background:lightgrey;" | | rowspan="2" {{N/A|''Photograph''}} | [[James Patrick Stuart]] |- | [[Kari Wahlgren]]
{{small|(infant)}} |- ! Derek Dietl | [[Paul Rudd]] | colspan="3" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | [[Nolan North]] |- ! Carl Murphy | [[Jeffrey Tambor]] | style="background:lightgrey;"|   | colspan="2" | Jeffrey Tambor | style="background:lightgrey;"|   |- ! King Coverton | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | [[Jeff Bennett]] |- ! Sqweep | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | [[Haley Tju]] |- ! Sta'abi | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | [[Gillian Jacobs]] |} ==Video games== The video game ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens (video game)|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' was released on March 24, 2009 on [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation 2]], and [[Wii]]. The game, developed by [[Beenox]] and [[Amaze Entertainment]], allows users to play through scenes from the movie as Ginormica, B.O.B., and The Missing Link, and features drop-in/out co-op. Players can play as Dr. Cockroach, PhD in multiplayer co-op, as well as Insectosaurus on the Nintendo DS version of the game. The music was composed by [[James Dooley (composer)|Jim Dooley]], with live brass recorded at the Warner Brothers Eastwood Scoring Stage.{{cite news | author=Dan Goldwasser | url=http://www.scoringsessions.com/news/168/ | title=Jim Dooley scores the ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' video game | publisher=ScoringSessions.com | date=March 9, 2009 | accessdate=March 15, 2009 }} The Monsters Vs. Aliens Videogame has garnered a Metacritic score of 63 for the Xbox 360 version of the title. Another video game titled ''[[Madagascar Kartz]]'' was released by Activision on October 27, 2009, for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Nintendo Wii, and Nintendo DS. Mainly based on the ''[[Madagascar (franchise)|Madagascar]]'' franchise, the game also features B.O.B.{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Craig|title=Madagascar Kartz Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/10/30/madagascar-kartz-review|publisher=IGN|accessdate=August 7, 2016|date=October 30, 2009}} and a racetrack based on the spaceship from ''Monsters vs. Aliens.''{{cite web|last1=Sykes|first1=Tom|title=Madagascar Kartz Review|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/madagascar-kartz-10/|publisher=GamesRadar|accessdate=August 7, 2016|date=November 13, 2009}} Another video game titled ''[[Super Star Kartz]]'' was released by Activision on November 15, 2011,{{cite web|title=DreamWorks Super Star Kartz|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/dreamworks-super-star-kartz|work=Metacritic|accessdate=October 28, 2011}} for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Nintendo Wii, Nintendo DS, and Nintendo 3DS. The game features 14 different characters from DreamWorks' films – ''Monsters vs. Aliens'', ''Madagascar'', ''Shrek'', and ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (franchise)|How to Train Your Dragon]]''.{{cite news|last=O'Connor|first=Alice|title=DreamWorks Super Star Kartz announced|url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/70085/dreamworks-super-star-kartz-announced|accessdate=October 28, 2011|newspaper=Shacknews|date=September 8, 2011}} A free mobile game, titled ''B.O.B.'s Super Freaky Job'', developed by Adrenaline, was released on October 10, 2013 to [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. In the game, player must guide B.O.B. through challenges by rotating the world around him, to obtain spare parts for Dr. Cockroach, and earn stars for the Presidential Medal.{{cite news|title=DreamWorks Animation And Adrenaline Unleash The Monsters With B.O.B.'s Super Freaky Job Mobile Game|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dreamworks-animation-and-adrenaline-unleash-the-monsters-with-bobs-super-freaky-job-mobile-game-227218261.html|accessdate=October 11, 2013|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=October 10, 2013}} ==Chronology== Chronological order of the ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' franchise history: # ''[[B.O.B.'s Big Break]]'' (2009) # ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' (2009) # ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space]]'' (2009) # ''[[Night of the Living Carrots|Monsters vs. Aliens: Night of the Living Carrots]]'' (2011) # [[Monsters vs. Aliens (TV series)|''Monsters vs. Aliens'']] (2013–2014) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.monstersvsaliens.com/}} {{Monsters vs. Aliens}} {{DreamWorks animated films}} [[Category:Science fiction by franchise]] [[Category:DreamWorks Animation franchises]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures franchises]] [[Category:Universal Studios franchises]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Film series introduced in 2009]] [[Category:American animated fantasy films]] [[Category:American animated science fiction films]] [[Category:Animated film series]] [[Category:Science fiction films by series]] [[Category:Comedy films by series]] [[Category:American monster movies]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Computer-animated films]] [[Category:Children's film series]]

revision.text:
[[File:Museum of Particularly Bad Art logo.jpg|right|180px|thumbnail|The logo for Museum of Particularly Bad Art. (Picture of [[Elvis]] and [[Priscilla Presley]])]] '''The Museum of Particularly Bad Art Exhibition''' (MOPBA) is an annual event held on [[Chapel Street]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] celebrating poor [[art]] forms, primarily in the forms of [[painting]]s and [[Sketch (drawing)|sketch]]es. MOPBA relies on a core group of art pieces owned by [[Helen Round]] but the public are invited to enter pieces that are their own or that have been found that are considered poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/eish/kitsch-becomes-an-artform-in-australia-418024|title=Kitsch becomes an artform in Australia - IOL News|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nrk.no/kultur/er-dette-arets-verste-kunstverk_-1.7300495|title=Er dette årets verste kunstverk?|first=|last=NRK|publisher=}}</ref> The event primarily is a charity event that funds three charities within the [[City of Stonnington|Stonnington]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/07/16/1089694559243.html|title=Art that's no oil painting - Arts - www.theage.com.au|website=www.theage.com.au}}</ref>
==Criteria== The entries from the public are judged by meeting one point on the selection criteria. Selection points for entry of an art piece into MOPBA are:
* Completely devoid of technical skill ([[Colour]], [[Lightness (color)|tone]], [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]] and [[shading]]); * Unusual, poor or tasteless subject matters; * Passion of the [[artist]] but is driven by an [[Amateur|uneducated hand]]; * An instinctual feeling that the art piece is poor. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100922/world/bad-art-in-australia.327977|title=Bad art in Australia|first=Allied Newspapers|last=Ltd|publisher=}}</ref>
==History== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Gary Glitter.jpg|right|thumbnail|"No one Wants to Touch Him There." ([[Gary Glitter]]). Materials: Crushed velvet, Acrylic and Glitter.]] --> [[Image:Windsor Junkie.jpg|left|300px|thumbnail|''Windsor Junkie circa 1896'' - Itchiball Prize Winner 2005.]] The founder of MOPBA is [[Helen Round]]. In the early 1990s, ''[[Foreign Correspondent (TV series)|Foreign Correspondent]]'' reported on the [[Museum of Bad Art]] in [[Dedham, Massachusetts|Dedham]], United States. At this point of her life, Round was in the process of establishing a retail shop named "Fat Helen’s Bric a Brac shop", that was to specialise in the [[kitsch]], inane and tasteless. It was also a hobby of Round's to peruse [[op shop]]s, [[garage sale]]s and [[Market (place)|market]]s. She was inspired by what she came across in these places and commenced her pursuit of collecting and preserving the mediocre. Round started collecting in 1993.<ref>{{cite web|title=Museum of Particularly Bad Art: About|url=http://www.mopba.org/?page_id=2|accessdate=2014-08-14}}</ref><ref name="spiegel">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/kunst-in-melbourne-museum-der-haesslichkeiten-a-583180.html|title=Kunst in Melbourne: Museum der Hässlichkeiten|date=9 October 2008|publisher=|via=Spiegel Online}}</ref>
Since then, Round has collected 200 examples of original art of poor taste. Of notable fame is the original portrait of [[actor]] [[Scott Baio]] that Round located in an op shop in the suburb of [[Windsor, Victoria|Windsor]] in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/suzanne-carbone/amanda-needs-love/2005/08/02/1122748636560.html|title=Amanda needs to be loved - Carbone & Money - Opinion - theage.com.au|website=www.theage.com.au}}</ref><ref name="spiegel"/>
The Exhibition awards the Itchiball Prize to the submitted art piece that is considered by the public to be the poorest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/deepend/dreadful-art/3339714|title=Dreadful art|date=8 August 2006|website=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> The name is a play on words and parody of the '[[Archibald Prize]]', Australia's most important [[portrait]]ure painting award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Itchyball Prize|url=http://www.mopba.org/?page_id=8|website=Museum of Particularly Bad Art|accessdate=2014-08-14}}</ref>

''''' Naissance du Cité'''''' was a "popular [[spectacle]]" held at the [[Vélodrome d'hiver]] on 18 October 1937 as part of the [[Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques dans la Vie Moderne]].<ref name="Art in France">{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=Christopher|title=Art in France, 1900-1940|date=2003|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300099088|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vlY6SLmg-xEC&pg=PA177&lpg=PA177&dq=%22Birth+of+a+City%22+Leger&source=bl&ots=jxYeIQmBM8&sig=XNjIYa8n8m8_tardBqzWtKpGNyw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjFq-XVt_HZAhUBWsAKHTSrBFsQ6AEIPTAH#v=onepage&q=%22Birth%20of%20a%20City%22%20Leger&f=false|accessdate=16 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> The [[auteur]] for the event was [[Jean-Richard Bloch]]
The spectacle was based around the story of an oil-rich colony led by an engineer which was threatened by an imperialist power. However, following the intervention of the [[League of Nations]], there was a decision to pool the world's resource and an era of endless peace was ushered in. The drama unrolled to the sound of horns and sirens, radio news flashes and during the finale not only were there wrestling matches and athletic events, but the cycle track of the Vélodrome d'hiver was used for a cycle race. There was a chorus - achieved by amplifying the voice of radio announcer, but original plans to project a film onto a big screen were dropped, in favour of an enormous back drop designed by [[Fernand Léger]].<ref name="Art in France"/>

'''Neo-[[Benshi]]''' is the practice of producing live alternate voice-overs for movies.
The art form’s acknowledged starting point is in Korea, Japan, Taiwan and other East Asian nations during the silent film era. [[Benshi]] is a Japanese word referring to the oral "interpreter" who performed a live narrative accompaniment to silent movies, in lieu of showing intertitles with dialogue, etc. In Korean the practice is known as pyônsa. Currently, it is finding a resurgence among experimental poets in the San Francisco Bay area and Los Angeles.
==Movietelling== Movietelling is a reinstatement, or retelling, of the film narrator practice(s). Long time practitioner and one of the foremost scholars on the subject of live film narration, Walter Lew, coined this phrase with the intention of reviving and revamping what he considers to have been an international practice, finding its roots throughout Europe, Asia, and the United States. In January 2008, Walter Lew, along with several poets and video artists, began shadoWord productions, an organization dedicated to the practice, as well as the evolution, of Movietelling.
==External links== *[[Linh Dinh]] on David Larsen and [http://poeticinvention.blogspot.com/2007/02/neo-benshi.html neo-benshi] *[http://benshi.org Da Benshi Code], with films of neo-benshi performances
