scope="row" | ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' | June 9, 2017 | [[Alex Kurtzman]] | [[Tom Cruise]] |style="text-align: center;"| 15% |style="text-align: center;"| 5.5 |- |} ===Dark Universe=== [[File:Dark Universe official logo.jpg|thumb|242x242px|Official logo of the Dark Universe, shared film universe as released by Universal Pictures]] Dark Universe is the term given by Universal Pictures to their planned [[cinematic universe]], which will be based on the classic Universal Monsters film series. The studio's first attempt at this universe was with the film ''[[Dracula Untold]]''. Released on October 10, 2014, with [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]] in the [[Count Dracula|titular role]], the film was developed prior to plans for a shared universe of horror films. However, it was retooled to be a part of the franchise. The film's mixed financial and critical reception resulted in the film's future status within the franchise becoming uncertain. Since the release of ''Dracula Untold'', the connections to the shared universe have been downplayed. Universal, which had announced plans to reboot [[The Mummy (franchise)|''The Mummy'' franchise]] in 2012, decided to re-position the new installment as the first film in the series. ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' was set to be released in 2017 with [[Alex Kurtzman]] as director.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Universal Stakes Out Release Date for Third Monster Movie|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|accessdate=September 24, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=What Universal Must Do To Sell Its Classic Monsters Universe|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#7772cec46b38|accessdate=September 24, 2016|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=July 13, 2016}} Also, Kurtzman and [[Chris Morgan (writer)|Chris Morgan]] were announced as headlining the Dark Universe, with collaborations from [[David Koepp]] and [[Christopher McQuarrie]].{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-may-1495481404-htmlstory.html|title=Universal debuts its spooky new Dark Universe and its upcoming 'Bride of Frankenstein'|publisher=''LA Times''|author=Woerner, Meredith|date=May 22, 2017}} Along with the crew, Universal announced the casting of [[Russell Crowe]] as [[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (character)|Dr. Henry Jekyll / Mr. Edward Hyde]], [[Javier Bardem]] as the [[Frankenstein's monster|Frankenstein Monster]], and [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Griffin (The Invisible Man)|The Invisible Man]]. They would join [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Sofia Boutella]], as Nick Morton and Princess Ahmanet / The Mummy. [[Bill Condon]] was announced as the director of the franchise's ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'', originally set to be released on February 14, 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2423971/its-been-one-year-since-the-dark-universe-was-announced-so-what-happened|title=It's Been One Year Since The Dark Universe Was Announced, So What Happened?|publisher=Cinema Blend|author=Holmes, Adam|date=May 2018}} Even though various sources claimed that Evans' character might have at least a cameo in ''The Mummy'' or any of the upcoming films in the universe, Kurtzman denied these claims, stating that he considered the film to not be a part of the ''Dark Universe''.{{cite web|last=Trumbore |first=Dave |date=December 4, 2016 |title='The Mummy': Alex Kurtzman Confirms 'Dracula Untold' Is Not Canon, Teases Jekyll's Role |url=http://collider.com/the-mummy-universal-monsters-shared-universe/#dracula-untold |publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] }} Additional rebooted versions of their characters were announced to have films in development as well including: the [[The Wolf Man (1941 film)|Wolf Man]], the [[Creature from the Black Lagoon]], the [[Phantom of the Opera (1943 film)|Phantom of the Opera]], and [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]. The shared film universe's official theme music was composed by [[Danny Elfman]]. On June 9, 2017, ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' was released.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Universal Stakes Out Release Date for Third Monster Movie|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|accessdate=September 24, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 3, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011035549/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|archivedate=October 11, 2016|df=}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=What Universal Must Do To Sell Its Classic Monsters Universe|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#b89e3026b382|accessdate=September 24, 2016|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=July 13, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927142045/http://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#b89e3026b382|archivedate=September 27, 2016|df=}}{{cite web |last=Armitage |first=Hugh |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/the-mummy/news/a830407/the-mummy-brendan-fraser-easter-eggs/ |title=Exclusive: Why ''The Mummy'' needed Brendan Fraser trilogy Easter eggs, according to director Alex Kurtzman |publisher=Digitalspy.com |date=June 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170626182450/http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/the-mummy/news/a830407/the-mummy-brendan-fraser-easter-eggs/ |archivedate=June 26, 2017 |df= }} The film received generally negative reviews from critics, and performed below the studio's expectations at the box office.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/the-mummy-reviews-roundup-1202457392/|title=‘The Mummy’ Reviews: What the Critics Are Saying|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 8, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607223217/http://variety.com/2017/film/news/the-mummy-reviews-roundup-1202457392/|archivedate=June 7, 2017|df=}} By November, ''The Bride of Frankenstein'' was pulled from its initial release, and lead producers/co-architects of the Dark Universe, [[Alex Kurtzman]] and [[Chris Morgan (writer)|Chris Morgan]], left Universal and departed from the franchise. Universal has put a hold on future projects while they create a plan for future releases.{{Cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/alex-kurtzman-chris-morgan-exit-universal-monsterverse-1055854 |title=Universal's 'Monsterverse' in Peril as Top Producers Exit (Exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]] |date=November 8, 2017}} [[Universal Pictures]] released an official statement reading: {{Quote|After thoughtful consideration, Universal Pictures and director [[Bill Condon]] have decided to postpone ''Bride of Frankenstein''. None of us want[s] to move too quickly to meet a release date when we know this special movie needs more time to come together. Bill is a director whose enormous talent has been proven time and again, and we all look forward to continuing to work on this film together.{{Cite news|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/uk/movies/the-mummy/53302/dark-universe-the-undignified-death-of-a-cinematic-universe|title=Dark Universe: the undignified death of a cinematic universe|work=Den of Geek|access-date=November 15, 2017|language=en}}}} By January 2018, development on the film progressed with Condon hiring a production team consisting of cinematographer [[Tobias A. Schliessler]], production designer [[Sarah Greenwood]], composer [[Carter Burwell]], and costume designer [[Jacqueline Durran]].{{cite web|last=Marc|first=Christopher|url=http://omegaunderground.com/2018/01/15/bill-condons-bride-frankenstein-assembles-production-team-will-shoot/|title=''Bride of Frankenstein'' Assembles Production Team - When Will It Shoot?|date=January 15, 2018|publisher=''Omega Underground''|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} In May of the same year, artist Robert Vargas announced from his social media account that he had attended a meeting with the studio and will collaborate on the Dark Universe films moving forward.{{cite web|last=Schaefer|first=Sandy|url=https://screenrant.com/dark-universe-monster-movies/|title=Universal's Dark Universe Might Not Be Dead After All|date=May 18, 2018|publisher=''ScreenRant''|accessdate=May 18, 2018}} Successful horror film producer [[Jason Blum]] has publicly expressed his interest in working on the Dark Universe franchise.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbr.com/jason-blum-dark-universe-interest/|title=Spawn Producer Jason Blum Interested In Reviving Dark Universe|date=18 August 2018|publisher=}} ==See also== *''[[The Monster Squad]]'' (1987) '''Animation''' *''[[Monster Force]]'' (1994) (TV series) *''[[Van Helsing: The London Assignment]]'' (2004) (DTV) *''[[The Mummy (TV series)|The Mummy: The Animated Series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Neibaur |first=James L. |title=The Monster Movies of Universal Studios |date=2017 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-1-44-227817-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-YrDgAAQBAJ}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Universal Monsters film series}} * [http://www.darkuniverse.com/ Dark Universe homepage] {{Universal Monsters}} [[Category:Film series introduced in 1923]] [[Category:Universal Studios]] [[Category:Universal Classic Monsters]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Horror film characters]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Fiction about monsters]]

'''World Wide Telecom Web''' (also called as '''Spoken Web''' or '''Telecom Web''') is an initiative to create an alternate web for the under-privileged. It could help bridge the [[digital divide]] by bringing the benefits of the information revolution to the billions of underserved people by providing information and services through a voice driven channel over an ordinary phone call. Information on this web could be community created as well as leveraged from [[World Wide Web]]. It is essentially a voice driven eco-system parallel and complementary to that of the existing [[World Wide Web|Web]].<ref name="WWTW">WWTW: The World Wide Telecom Web, In Proceedings of ACM SIGCOMM Workshop on Networked Systems for Developing Regions (NSDR), August 2007, Kyoto, Japan.</ref> Though primarily meant for the under-served in population in emerging economies, it has several applications for the developed world as well.<ref>[http://researcher.watson.ibm.com/researcher/view_person_subpage.php?id=1649 The World Wide Telecom Web -]</ref>
WWTW can be accessible to more number of people in the world as it enables an ordinary phone subscriber to join the digital information revolution. This enables a significantly larger fraction of the human population to benefit from existing and envisioned services than what was made possible by WWW. Specifically, it removes accessibility barriers that manifest themselves in terms of illiteracy, unaffordability and lack of relevant information. Further, it provides the means to create and sustain an ecosystem of local (and global) services, information and communities relevant to these underprivileged users.<ref name="WWTW"/>
==How it works== WWTW is a network of interconnected '''VoiceSites''' (analogous to web sites) that are voice driven applications ''created by'' users themselves and ''hosted'' in the telecom network. VoiceSites can be interconnected using 'VoiLinks' (analogous to hyperlinks) which are links between two voice applications within the web. VoiLinks can span across different enterprises enabling cross-organizational workflows driven by a voice interface over an ordinary phone.
Key enabler technologies include:
1. VoiGen - VoiceSite Creator
2. VoiHost - VoiceSite Hosting Engine
3. [[HSTP]] - Hyperspeech Transfer Protocol
4. WWTW Browser - World Wide Telecom Web Browser
==Brief history== World Wide Telecom Web was conceived by [http://researcher.ibm.com/view.php?person=in-kkarun Arun Kumar] at [[IBM]] [http://www.research.ibm.com/irl/ India Research Lab] during late 2004 and was later joined by fellow researcher [http://domino.research.ibm.com/comm/research_people.nsf/pages/rajput.index.html Nitendra Rajput] in mid-2005. Originally, WWTW was primarily viewed as a novel application of speech technology and [[VoiceXML]] standard even though use of VoiceSites for under-privileged was one of the listed benefits. During the course of a year, they refined the vision and built a couple of primitive prototypes of VoiceSite generator application christened VoiGen, with the help of fellow researcher [http://domino.research.ibm.com/comm/research_people.nsf/pages/chakraborty.index.html Dipanjan Chakraborty] and colleague Sandeep Jindal & Rajiv Goyal. In late 2006, inspired by Prof. [[C.K. Prahalad]] and led by Ponani Gopalakrishnan (then the director of IBM India Research Lab), Arun and Nitendra along with Dipanjan and [http://domino.research.ibm.com/comm/research_people.nsf/pages/nanavati.index.html Amit Anil Nanavati] got funded for an Exploratory Research project to develop technologies for people towards the Base of the Pyramid. Here, WWTW shot into prominence and got recognized as the most compelling ecosystem for illiterate, low earning population of developing countries such as India. The team reported the work done so far in a [http://domino.research.ibm.com/library/cyberdig.nsf/1e4115aea78b6e7c85256b360066f0d4/9fb1978638a52de5852572890036ddc2?OpenDocument Research Report]. Soon after [http://www.csee.umbc.edu/~sheetal2/ Sheetal K. Agarwal] joined the team. Together this team designed and built the initial technological building blocks of Telecom Web details of which can be found in publications available at [http://domino.research.ibm.com/comm/research_people.nsf/pages/arun_kumar.wwtwpubs.html World Wide Telecom Web Publications]. This included creation of technology for enabling voice driven workflows spanning across organizational boundaries. Arun proposed the use of out-of-band-signaling mechanism, followed in telecom networks to achieve this. The resulting Hyperspeech Transfer Protocol (HSTP) got designed and created by the team as an HTTP equivalent protocol that enables voice hyperlinks in VoiceSites. The team designed and built the first prototype of this protocol in mid-2007 and reported it in Hypertext Conference in September 2007. The first successful field trial of VoiceSites as a powerful platform for underprivileged population came in the form of [http://www2008.org/papers/pdf/p1123-agarwal.pdf Voikiosk] system conceived primarily by Nitendra. It is a village portal providing locally relevant content in local language and is available over an ordinary telephone call.
